page.title: 01Blawith Fell & Woodland
page.content: This block contains 2 contrasting sections. The eastern half is mainly hilly, rocky moorland. The slopes of the hills are covered with bracken, gorse & heather. The lower lying areas are wetland & sheep may be found grazing throughout. When viewed from the summit of Blawith Fell (highest point in block) in mid October, the moorland looks a mass of greens, browns, purples & greys. South of Blawith Fell, Beacon Tarn breaks up the monotony of the hills. It is an area popular with walkers & the Cumbria Way footpath passes by Beacon Tarn & crosses the summit of Blawith Fell. The western half of the block is mainly rough grazing land, but there is also a considerable amount of wood- land. The main occupation appears to be dairy farming. The only public transport in the area is a twice daily
